line: 7 Syntax
label: heading

line: 7.1 General
label: heading

line: This clause covers everything about the syntax of PDF at the object, file, and document level. It sets the stage
label: paragraph

line: for subsequent clauses, which describe how the contents of a PDF file are interpreted as page descriptions,
label: paragraph

line: interactive navigational aids, and application-level logical structure.
label: paragraph

line: PDF syntax is best understood by considering it as four parts, as shown in Figure 1:
label: paragraph

line: Objects. A PDF document is a data structure composed from a small set of basic types of data objects.
label: paragraph

line: Sub-clause 7.2, "Lexical Conventions," describes the character set used to write objects and other
label: paragraph

line: syntactic elements. Sub-clause 7.3, "Objects," describes the syntax and essential properties of the objects.
label: paragraph

line: Sub-clause 7.3.8, "Stream Objects," provides complete details of the most complex data type, the stream
label: paragraph

line: object.
label: paragraph

line: File structure. The PDF file structure determines how objects are stored in a PDF file, how they are
label: paragraph

line: accessed, and how they are updated. This structure is independent of the semantics of the objects. Sub-
label: paragraph

line: clause 7.5, "File Structure," describes the file structure. Sub-clause 7.6, "Encryption," describes a file-level
label: paragraph

line: mechanism for protecting a document’s contents from unauthorized access.
label: paragraph

line: Document structure. The PDF document structure specifies how the basic object types are used to
label: paragraph

line: represent components
label: paragraph

line: "Document Structure,"
label: paragraph

line: of a PDF document: pages, fonts, annotations, and so forth. Sub-clause 7.7,
label: paragraph

line: describes the overall document structure; later clauses address the detailed
label: paragraph

line: semantics of the components.
label: paragraph

line: Content streams. A PDF content stream contains a sequence of instructions describing the appearance of
label: paragraph

line: a page or other graphical entity. These instructions, while also represented as objects, are conceptually
label: paragraph

line: distinct from the objects that represent the document structure and are described separately. Sub-clause
label: paragraph

line: 7.8, "Content Streams and Resources," discusses PDF content streams and their associated resources.
label: paragraph

line: Figure 1 – PDF Components
label: heading

line: In addition, this clause describes some data structures, built from basic objects, that are so widely used that
label: paragraph

line: they can almost be considered basic object types in their own right. These
label: paragraph

line: "Common Data Structures"; 7.10, "Functions"; and 7.11, "File Specifications."
label: paragraph

line: objects are covered in: 7.9,
label: paragraph

line: NOTE Variants of PDF’s object and file syntax are also used as the basis for other file formats. These include the
label: paragraph

line: Forms Data Format (FDF), described in 12.7.7, "Forms Data Format", and the Portable Job Ticket Format
label: paragraph

line: (PJTF), described in Adobe Technical Note #5620, Portable Job Ticket Format.
label: paragraph

line: 7.2 Lexical Conventions
label: heading

line: 7.2.1 General
label: heading

line: At the most fundamental level, a PDF file is a sequence of bytes. These bytes can be grouped into tokens
label: paragraph

line: according to the syntax rules described in this sub-clause. One or more tokens are assembled to form higher-
label: paragraph

line: © Adobe Systems Incorporated 2008 – All rights reserved
label: paragraph

line: level syntactic entities, principally objects, which are the basic data values from which a PDF document is
label: paragraph

line: constructed.
label: paragraph

line: A non-encrypted PDF can be entirely represented using byte values corresponding to the visible printable
label: paragraph

line: subset of the character set defined in ANSI X3.4-1986, plus white space characters. However, a PDF file is not
label: paragraph

line: restricted to the ASCII character set; it may contain arbitrary bytes, subject to the following considerations:
label: paragraph

line: The tokens that delimit objects and that describe the structure of a PDF file shall use the ASCII character
label: paragraph

line: set. In addition all the reserved words and the names used as keys in PDF standard dictionaries and
label: paragraph

line: certain types of arrays shall be defined using the ASCII character set.
label: paragraph

line: The data values of strings and streams objects may be written either entirely using the ASCII character set
label: paragraph

line: or entirely in binary data. In actual practice, data that is naturally binary, such as sampled images, is
label: paragraph

line: usually represented in binary for compactness and efficiency.
label: paragraph

line: A PDF file containing binary data shall be transported as a binary file rather than as a text file to insure that
label: paragraph

line: all bytes of the file are faithfully preserved.
label: paragraph

line: NOTE 1 A binary file is not portable to environments that impose reserved character codes, maximum line lengths, end-
label: paragraph

line: of-line conventions, or other restrictions
label: paragraph

line: NOTE 2 In this clause, the usage of the term character is entirely independent of any logical meaning that the value
label: paragraph

line: may have when it is treated as data in specific contexts, such as representing human-readable text or
label: paragraph

line: selecting a glyph from a font.
label: paragraph

line: 7.2.2 Character Set
label: heading

line: The PDF character set is divided into three classes, called regular, delimiter, and white-space characters. This
label: paragraph

line: classification determines the grouping of characters into tokens. The rules defined in this sub-clause apply to
label: paragraph

line: all characters in the file except within strings, streams, and comments.
label: paragraph

line: The White-space characters shown in Table 1 separate syntactic constructs such as names and numbers from
label: paragraph

line: each other. All white-space characters are equivalent, except in comments, strings, and streams. In all other
label: paragraph

line: contexts, PDF treats any sequence of consecutive white-space characters as one character.
label: paragraph

line: Table 1 – White-space characters
label: heading

line: The CARRIAGE RETURN (0Dh) and LINE FEED (0Ah) characters, also called newline characters, shall be
label: paragraph

line: treated as end-of-line (EOL) markers. The combination of a CARRIAGE RETURN followed immediately by a
label: paragraph

line: LINE FEED shall be treated as one EOL marker. EOL markers may be treated the same as any other white-
label: paragraph

line: space characters. However, sometimes an EOL marker is required or recommended—that is, preceding a
label: paragraph

line: token that must appear at the beginning of a line.
label: paragraph

line: NOTE The examples in this standard use a convention that arranges tokens into lines. However, the examples’ use of
label: paragraph

line: white space for indentation is purely for clarity of exposition and need not be included in practical use.
label: paragraph

line: © Adobe Systems Incorporated 2008 – All rights reserved
label: paragraph

line: The delimiter characters (, ), <, >, [, ], {, }, /, and % are special
label: paragraph

line: (LEFT PARENTHESIS (28h), RIGHT
label: paragraph

line: PARENTHESIS (29h), LESS-THAN SIGN (3Ch), GREATER-THAN SIGN (3Eh), LEFT SQUARE BRACKET
label: paragraph

line: (5Bh), RIGHT SQUARE BRACKET (5Dh), LEFT CURLY BRACE (7Bh), RIGHT CURLY BRACE (07Dh),
label: paragraph

line: SOLIDUS (2Fh) and PERCENT SIGN (25h), respectively). They delimit syntactic entities such as arrays,
label: paragraph

line: names, and comments. Any of these characters terminates the entity preceding it and is not included in the
label: paragraph

line: entity. Delimiter characters are allowed within the scope of a string when following the rules for composing
label: paragraph

line: strings; see 7.3.4.2, “Literal Strings”. The leading ( of a string does delimit a preceding entity and the closing ) of
label: paragraph

line: a string delimits the string’s end.
label: paragraph

line: Table 2 – Delimiter characters
label: heading

line: All characters except the white-space characters and delimiters are referred to as regular characters. These
label: paragraph

line: characters include bytes that are outside the ASCII character set. A sequence of consecutive regular
label: paragraph

line: characters comprises a single token. PDF is case-sensitive; corresponding uppercase and lowercase letters
label: paragraph

line: shall be considered distinct.
label: paragraph

line: 7.2.3 Comments
label: heading

line: Any occurrence of the PERCENT SIGN (25h) outside a string or stream introduces a comment. The comment
label: paragraph

line: consists of all characters after the PERCENT SIGN and up to but not including the end of the line, including
label: paragraph

line: regular, delimiter, SPACE (20h), and HORZONTAL TAB characters (09h). A conforming reader shall ignore
label: paragraph

line: comments, and treat them as single white-space characters. That is, a comment separates the token preceding
label: paragraph

line: it from the one following it.
label: paragraph

line: EXAMPLE The PDF fragment in this example is syntactically equivalent to just the tokens abc and 123.
label: paragraph

line: a bc% comment ( /% ) blah blah blah
label: paragraph

line: Comments (other than the %PDF–n.m and %%EOF comments described in 7.5, "File Structure") have no
label: paragraph

line: semantics. They are not necessarily preserved by applications that edit PDF files.
label: paragraph

line: 7.3 Objects
label: heading

line: 7.3.1 General
label: heading

line: PDF includes eight basic types of objects: Boolean values, Integer and Real numbers, Strings, Names, Arrays,
label: paragraph

line: Dictionaries, Streams, and the null object.
label: paragraph
